message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Quantum complexity of time evolution with chaotic Hamiltonians
Paper Abstract: We study the quantum complexity of time evolution in large-N chaotic systems, with the SYK model as our main example. This complexity is expected to increase linearly for exponential time prior to saturating at its maximum value, and is related to the length of minimal geodesics on the manifold of unitary operators that act on Hilbert space. Using the Euler-Arnold formalism, we demonstrate that there is always a geodesic between the identity and the time evolution operator e -iHt whose length grows linearly with time. This geodesic is minimal until there is an obstruction to its minimality, after which it can fail to be a minimum either locally or globally. We identify a criterion — the Eigenstate Complexity Hypothesis (ECH) — which bounds the overlap between offdiagonal energy eigenstate projectors and the k-local operators of the theory, and use it to argue that the linear geodesic will at least be a local minimum for exponential time. We show numerically that the large-N SYK model (which is chaotic) satisfies ECH and thus has no local obstructions to linear growth of complexity for exponential time, as expected from holographic duality. In contrast, we also study the case with N = 2 fermions (which is integrable) and find short-time linear complexity growth followed by oscillations. Our analysis relates complexity to familiar properties of physical theories like their spectra and the structure of energy eigenstates and has implications for the hypothesized computational complexity class separations PSPACE * BQP/poly and PSPACE * BQSUBEXP/subexp, and the “fast-forwarding” of quantum Hamiltonians.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of Hamiltonian mechanics:

## Definition and Overview

In physics, Hamiltonian mechanics is a reformulation of Lagrangian mechanics that emerged in 1833.(no content)Introduced by Sir William Rowan Hamilton, Hamiltonian mechanics replaces (generalized) velocities used in Lagrangian mechanics with (generalized) momenta.

## Key Concepts

Any smooth real-valued function H on a symplectic manifold can be used to define a Hamiltonian system. The function H is known as "the Hamiltonian" or "the energy function." The symplectic manifold is then called the phase space.(no content)A simple interpretation of Hamiltonian mechanics comes from its application on a one-dimensional system consisting of one nonrelativistic particle of mass m. The value of the Hamiltonian is the total energy of the system, in this case the sum of kinetic and potential energy. Here p is the momentum mv and q is the space coordinate.

## Applications and Significance

Both theories provide interpretations of classical mechanics and describe the same physical phenomena. Hamiltonian mechanics has a close relationship with geometry (notably, symplectic geometry and Poisson structures) and serves as a link between classical and quantum mechanics.(no content)A Hamiltonian system is a dynamical system governed by Hamilton's equations. In physics, this dynamical system describes the evolution of a physical system such as a planetary system or an electron in an electromagnetic field.

Web search results for query: "Geodesic"

Links: [{"title":"Geodesic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodesic"},{"title":"Geodesic map - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodesic_map"},{"title":"Geodesic curvature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodesic_curvature"},{"title":"Geodesic dome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodesic_dome"},{"title":"Solving the geodesic equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solving_the_geodesic_equations"},{"title":"Geodesic manifold - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodesic_manifold"},{"title":"Complex geodesic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_geodesic"},{"title":"ASM Headquarters and Geodesic Dome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASM_Headquarters_and_Geodesic_Dome"},{"title":"Geodesic circle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodesic_circle"},{"title":"List of geodesic polyhedra and Goldberg polyhedra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_geodesic_polyhedra_and_Goldberg_polyhedra"}]

Here are the key search results about "Geodesic":

## Definition

In geometry, a geodesic is a curve representing in some sense the locally shortest path (arc) between two points in a surface, or more generally in a Riemannian manifold.(no content)It is a generalization of the notion of a "straight line".

## Key Characteristics

Geodesics are only locally the shortest distance between points, and are parameterized with "constant speed". For example, going the "long way round" on a great circle between two points on a sphere is a geodesic but not the shortest path between the points.

## Applications

Geodesics are commonly seen in the study of Riemannian geometry and more generally metric geometry. In general relativity, geodesics in spacetime describe the motion of point particles under the influence of gravity alone.(no content)In particular, the path taken by a falling rock, an orbiting satellite, or the shape of a planetary orbit are all geodesics in curved spacetime.

## Historical Origin

The term comes from geodesy, the science of measuring the size and shape of Earth, and in the original sense, a geodesic was the shortest route between two points on the Earth's surface.(no content)For a spherical Earth, it is a segment of a great circle.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Unitary operator"

Links: [{"title":"Unitary operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitary_operator"},{"title":"Talk:Unitary operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Unitary_operator"},{"title":"Unitary transformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitary_transformation"},{"title":"Unitary transformation (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitary_transformation_(quantum_mechanics)"},{"title":"Category:Unitary operators - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unitary_operators"},{"title":"Antiunitary operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiunitary_operator"},{"title":"Unitary matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitary_matrix"},{"title":"Unitarity (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitarity_(physics)"},{"title":"Corepresentations of unitary and antiunitary groups - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corepresentations_of_unitary_and_antiunitary_groups"},{"title":"Squeeze operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squeeze_operator"}]

## Unitary Operator

A unitary operator is a bounded linear operator U : H → H on a Hilbert space H that preserves the inner product of the Hilbert space. Unitary operators are automorphisms of Hilbert spaces, i.e., they preserve the structure (the vector space structure, the inner product, and hence the topology) of the space on which they act.

### Key Properties

The group of all unitary operators from a given Hilbert space H to itself is sometimes referred to as the Hilbert group of H, denoted Hilb(H) or U(H).

### Examples

Several important examples of unitary operators include:

- Rotations in R² are a simple nontrivial example of unitary operators, as they do not change the length of a vector or the angle between two vectors.
- In general, any operator in a Hilbert space that acts by permuting an orthonormal basis is unitary. In the finite dimensional case, such operators are the permutation matrices.
- On the vector space C of complex numbers, multiplication by a number of absolute value 1, that is, a number of the form e^(iθ), is a unitary operator.
- The Fourier operator is a unitary operator, i.e. the operator that performs the Fourier transform (with proper normalization).
- Quantum logic gates are unitary operators.

### Applications in Quantum Mechanics

In quantum physics, unitarity is the condition that the time evolution of a quantum state according to the Schrödinger equation is mathematically represented by a unitary operator.

Links: [{"title":"Unitary operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitary_operator"},{"title":"Talk:Unitary operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Unitary_operator"},{"title":"Unitary transformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitary_transformation"},{"title":"Unitary transformation (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitary_transformation_(quantum_mechanics)"},{"title":"Category:Unitary operators - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unitary_operators"},{"title":"Antiunitary operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiunitary_operator"},{"title":"Unitary matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitary_matrix"},{"title":"Unitarity (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitarity_(physics)"},{"title":"Corepresentations of unitary and antiunitary groups - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corepresentations_of_unitary_and_antiunitary_groups"},{"title":"Squeeze operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squeeze_operator"}]

## Unitary Operator

A unitary operator is a bounded linear operator U : H → H on a Hilbert space H that preserves the inner product of the Hilbert space. Unitary operators are automorphisms of Hilbert spaces, i.e., they preserve the structure (the vector space structure, the inner product, and hence the topology) of the space on which they act.

### Key Properties

The group of all unitary operators from a given Hilbert space H to itself is sometimes referred to as the Hilbert group of H, denoted Hilb(H) or U(H).

### Examples

Several important examples of unitary operators include:

- Rotations in R² are a simple nontrivial example of unitary operators, as they do not change the length of a vector or the angle between two vectors.
- In general, any operator in a Hilbert space that acts by permuting an orthonormal basis is unitary. In the finite dimensional case, such operators are the permutation matrices.
- On the vector space C of complex numbers, multiplication by a number of absolute value 1, that is, a number of the form e^(iθ), is a unitary operator.
- The Fourier operator is a unitary operator, i.e. the operator that performs the Fourier transform (with proper normalization).
- Quantum logic gates are unitary operators.

### Applications in Quantum Mechanics

In quantum physics, unitarity is the condition that the time evolution of a quantum state according to the Schrödinger equation is mathematically represented by a unitary operator.

Here are the search results for "Energy eigenstate":

## Overview

An energy eigenstate is a quantum state with all observables independent of time and is an eigenvector of the energy operator. It is also called energy eigenvector, energy eigenfunction, or energy eigenket.

## Key Characteristics

Energy eigenstates are quantum states that are solutions to the time-independent Schrödinger equation. All observable properties of the state are in fact constant in time.

The measurable values of the energy of a quantum system are given by the eigenvalues of the Hamiltonian operator, while its eigenstates give the possible energy states of the system.

## Examples and Applications

In the hydrogen atom, the 1s, 2s, 2p, and similar states are all stationary states, which are examples of energy eigenstates.

In quantum mechanics, the variational method is one way of finding approximations to the lowest energy eigenstate or ground state, and some excited states.

Energy eigenstates are fundamental to understanding quantum systems, particularly in problems like the particle in a box model, where a particle may only occupy certain positive energy levels and can never have zero energy.

Web search results for query: "Time evolution quantum mechanics"

Links: [{"title":"Time evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_evolution"},{"title":"Schrödinger picture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schr%C3%B6dinger_picture"},{"title":"Quantum mechanics of time travel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_mechanics_of_time_travel"},{"title":"Schrödinger equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schr%C3%B6dinger_equation"},{"title":"Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_(quantum_mechanics)"},{"title":"Unitarity (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitarity_(physics)"},{"title":"Problem of time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Problem_of_time"},{"title":"Heisenberg picture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heisenberg_picture"},{"title":"Quantum mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_mechanics"},{"title":"Wave packet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wave_packet"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of time evolution in quantum mechanics:

## Definition and Basic Concept

Time evolution is the change of state brought about by the passage of time, applicable to systems with internal state. In quantum mechanics, this describes how quantum systems change over time.

## Mathematical Framework

In quantum mechanics, the propagators are usually unitary operators on a Hilbert space. The evolution for a closed quantum system is brought about by a unitary operator, the time evolution operator.

## The Schrödinger Equation

The Schrödinger equation gives the evolution over time of the wave function, the quantum-mechanical characterization of an isolated physical system. While the time-evolution process represented by the Schrödinger equation is continuous and deterministic, in that knowing the wave function at one instant is in principle sufficient to calculate it for all future times, wave functions can also change discontinuously and stochastically during a measurement.

## Different Formulations

There are two main perspectives for describing time evolution:

1. **Schrödinger Picture**: In the Schrödinger picture, the state vectors evolve in time, but the operators (observables and others) are mostly constant with respect to time.

2. **Heisenberg Picture**: In the Heisenberg picture, observables incorporate a dependency on time, but the states are time-independent.

## Unitarity

In quantum physics, unitarity is the condition that the time evolution of a quantum state according to the Schrödinger equation is mathematically represented by a unitary operator.

Web search results for query: "Quantum complexity"

Links: [{"title":"Quantum complexity theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_complexity_theory"},{"title":"Exact quantum polynomial time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EQP_(complexity)"},{"title":"BQP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BQP"},{"title":"Quantum algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_algorithm"},{"title":"Quantum computational chemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computational_chemistry"},{"title":"QIP (complexity) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QIP_(complexity)"},{"title":"Harry Buhrman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Buhrman"},{"title":"CA-duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CA-duality"},{"title":"Category:Quantum complexity theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Quantum_complexity_theory"},{"title":"Quantum computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computing"}]

Based on the search results, here's what quantum complexity encompasses:

## Overview

Quantum complexity theory is the subfield of computational complexity theory that deals with complexity classes defined using quantum computers, a computational model based on quantum mechanics. 

## Key Focus Areas

One of the main aims of quantum complexity theory is to find out how these classes relate to classical complexity classes such as P, NP, BPP, and PSPACE.

## Important Complexity Classes

Several key quantum complexity classes have been identified:

- **BQP (Bounded-error Quantum Polynomial Time)**: BQP is the set of decision problems solvable by a quantum computer in polynomial time with error probability of at most 1/3 for all instances. It is the quantum analogue to the classical complexity class BPP.

- **EQP (Exact Quantum Polynomial Time)**: Exact quantum polynomial time is the class of decision problems that can be solved by a quantum computer with zero error probability and in guaranteed worst-case polynomial time.

- **QIP (Quantum Interactive Proof)**: The class QIP is the quantum computing analogue of the classical complexity class IP, which is the set of problems solvable by an interactive proof system with a polynomial-time verifier and one computationally unbounded prover.

## Query Complexity

Quantum query complexity refers to how complex, or how many queries to the graph associated with the solution of a particular problem, are required to solve the problem.

## Potential Advantages

One major advantage of using a quantum computational system instead of a classical one, is that a quantum computer may be able to give a polynomial time algorithm for some problem for which no classical polynomial time algorithm exists, but more importantly, a quantum computer may significantly decrease the calculation time for a problem that a classical computer can already solve efficiently.

Links: [{"title":"Quantum complexity theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_complexity_theory"},{"title":"Exact quantum polynomial time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EQP_(complexity)"},{"title":"BQP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BQP"},{"title":"Quantum algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_algorithm"},{"title":"Quantum computational chemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computational_chemistry"},{"title":"QIP (complexity) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QIP_(complexity)"},{"title":"Harry Buhrman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Buhrman"},{"title":"CA-duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CA-duality"},{"title":"Category:Quantum complexity theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Quantum_complexity_theory"},{"title":"Quantum computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computing"}]

Based on the search results, here's what quantum complexity encompasses:

## Overview

Quantum complexity theory is the subfield of computational complexity theory that deals with complexity classes defined using quantum computers, a computational model based on quantum mechanics. 

## Key Focus Areas

One of the main aims of quantum complexity theory is to find out how these classes relate to classical complexity classes such as P, NP, BPP, and PSPACE.

## Important Complexity Classes

Several key quantum complexity classes have been identified:

- **BQP (Bounded-error Quantum Polynomial Time)**: BQP is the set of decision problems solvable by a quantum computer in polynomial time with error probability of at most 1/3 for all instances. It is the quantum analogue to the classical complexity class BPP.

- **EQP (Exact Quantum Polynomial Time)**: Exact quantum polynomial time is the class of decision problems that can be solved by a quantum computer with zero error probability and in guaranteed worst-case polynomial time.

- **QIP (Quantum Interactive Proof)**: The class QIP is the quantum computing analogue of the classical complexity class IP, which is the set of problems solvable by an interactive proof system with a polynomial-time verifier and one computationally unbounded prover.

## Query Complexity

Quantum query complexity refers to how complex, or how many queries to the graph associated with the solution of a particular problem, are required to solve the problem.

## Potential Advantages

One major advantage of using a quantum computational system instead of a classical one, is that a quantum computer may be able to give a polynomial time algorithm for some problem for which no classical polynomial time algorithm exists, but more importantly, a quantum computer may significantly decrease the calculation time for a problem that a classical computer can already solve efficiently.

Here's what I found about BQP quantum complexity:

## Definition

BQP (bounded-error quantum polynomial time) is the class of decision problems solvable by a quantum computer in polynomial time, with an error probability of at most 1/3 for all instances.(no content)It is the quantum analogue to the complexity class BPP.

## Key Characteristics

The choice of 1/3 error probability is arbitrary, and by running the algorithm multiple times and taking a majority vote, any desired probability of correctness can be achieved.(no content)Like P and BPP, BQP is low for itself, meaning BQP^BQP = BQP.

## Relationships to Other Complexity Classes

It is known that P ⊆ BQP ⊆ PSPACE; that is, BQP includes all problems efficiently solvable by deterministic classical computers but does not include any problems that cannot be solved by classical computers with polynomial space resources.(no content)BQP is a subset of PP.(no content)It is suspected that BQP is a strict superset of P, and integer factorization and the discrete logarithm problem are known to be in BQP and are suspected to be outside of P.(no content)It is believed that NP is not contained in BQP, and consequently, it is suspected that BQP is disjoint from the class of NP-complete problems.

Links: [{"title":"Hilbert space - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert_space"},{"title":"Reproducing kernel Hilbert space - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproducing_kernel_Hilbert_space"},{"title":"Fundamental theorem of Hilbert spaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fundamental_theorem_of_Hilbert_spaces"},{"title":"Talk:Hilbert space - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Hilbert_space"},{"title":"Positive operator (Hilbert space) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive_operator_(Hilbert_space)"},{"title":"Category:Hilbert spaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Hilbert_spaces"},{"title":"Hilbert curve - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert_curve"},{"title":"Category of finite-dimensional Hilbert spaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category_of_finite-dimensional_Hilbert_spaces"},{"title":"Phase-space wavefunctions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase-space_wavefunctions"},{"title":"Auxiliary normed space - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auxiliary_normed_space"}]

## Summary of Search Results for "Hilbert Space"

Here's what I found about Hilbert spaces:

### Definition
A Hilbert space is a real or complex inner product space that is also a complete metric space with respect to the metric induced by the inner product.(no content)It generalizes the notion of Euclidean space to infinite dimensions.

### Key Properties
The inner product, which is the analog of the dot product from vector calculus, allows lengths and angles to be defined.(no content)Completeness means that there are enough limits in the space to allow the techniques of calculus to be used.

### Historical Development
Hilbert spaces were studied beginning in the first decade of the 20th century by David Hilbert, Erhard Schmidt, and Frigyes Riesz.(no content)John von Neumann coined the term Hilbert space for the abstract concept that underlies many of these diverse applications.

### Applications
They are indispensable tools in the theories of partial differential equations, quantum mechanics, Fourier analysis (which includes applications to signal processing and heat transfer), and ergodic theory (which forms the mathematical underpinning of thermodynamics).(no content)Examples of Hilbert spaces include spaces of square-integrable functions, spaces of sequences, Sobolev spaces consisting of generalized functions, and Hardy spaces of holomorphic functions.

Web search results for query: "Holographic duality"

Links: [{"title":"Holographic principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holographic_principle"},{"title":"AdS/CFT correspondence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AdS/CFT_correspondence"},{"title":"Algebraic holography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_holography"},{"title":"Duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_(physics)"},{"title":"List of dualities - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_dualities"},{"title":"Montonen–Olive duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montonen–Olive_duality"},{"title":"String theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/String_theory"},{"title":"CA-duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CA-duality"},{"title":"T-duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-duality"},{"title":"Time-domain holography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-domain_holography"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about holographic duality:

## Overview

The AdS/CFT correspondence is often described as a "holographic duality" because this relationship between the two theories is similar to the relationship between a three-dimensional object and its image as a hologram.(no content)Although a hologram is two-dimensional, it encodes information about all three dimensions of the object it represents. In the same way, theories that are related by the AdS/CFT correspondence are conjectured to be exactly equivalent, despite living in different numbers of dimensions.

## Historical Background

The holographic principle is a property of string theories and a supposed property of quantum gravity that states that the description of a volume of space can be thought of as encoded on a lower-dimensional boundary to the region. First proposed by Gerard 't Hooft in 1993, it was given a precise string theoretic interpretation by Leonard Susskind.(no content)The AdS/CFT correspondence was first proposed by Juan Maldacena in late 1997.

## Significance

The duality represents a major advance in understanding of string theory and quantum gravity because it provides a non-perturbative formulation of string theory with certain boundary conditions and because it is the most successful realization of the holographic principle.(no content)Much of the usefulness of the duality results from a strong-weak duality: when the fields of the quantum field theory are strongly interacting, the ones in the gravitational theory are weakly interacting and thus more mathematically tractable. This fact has been used to study many aspects of nuclear and condensed matter physics by translating problems in those subjects into more mathematically tractable problems in string theory.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Holographic principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holographic_principle"},{"title":"AdS/CFT correspondence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AdS/CFT_correspondence"},{"title":"Algebraic holography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_holography"},{"title":"Duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_(physics)"},{"title":"List of dualities - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_dualities"},{"title":"Montonen–Olive duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montonen–Olive_duality"},{"title":"String theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/String_theory"},{"title":"CA-duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CA-duality"},{"title":"T-duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-duality"},{"title":"Time-domain holography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-domain_holography"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about holographic duality:

## Overview

The AdS/CFT correspondence is often described as a "holographic duality" because this relationship between the two theories is similar to the relationship between a three-dimensional object and its image as a hologram.(no content)Although a hologram is two-dimensional, it encodes information about all three dimensions of the object it represents. In the same way, theories that are related by the AdS/CFT correspondence are conjectured to be exactly equivalent, despite living in different numbers of dimensions.

## Historical Background

The holographic principle is a property of string theories and a supposed property of quantum gravity that states that the description of a volume of space can be thought of as encoded on a lower-dimensional boundary to the region. First proposed by Gerard 't Hooft in 1993, it was given a precise string theoretic interpretation by Leonard Susskind.(no content)The AdS/CFT correspondence was first proposed by Juan Maldacena in late 1997.

## Significance

The duality represents a major advance in understanding of string theory and quantum gravity because it provides a non-perturbative formulation of string theory with certain boundary conditions and because it is the most successful realization of the holographic principle.(no content)Much of the usefulness of the duality results from a strong-weak duality: when the fields of the quantum field theory are strongly interacting, the ones in the gravitational theory are weakly interacting and thus more mathematically tractable. This fact has been used to study many aspects of nuclear and condensed matter physics by translating problems in those subjects into more mathematically tractable problems in string theory.

Web search results for query: "PSPACE complexity class"

Links: [{"title":"PSPACE - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PSPACE"},{"title":"PSPACE-complete - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PSPACE-complete"},{"title":"Polynomial hierarchy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynomial_hierarchy"},{"title":"Complexity class - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complexity_class"},{"title":"EXPTIME - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EXPTIME"},{"title":"NSPACE - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NSPACE"},{"title":"Space complexity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_complexity"},{"title":"IP (complexity) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IP_(complexity)"},{"title":"P (complexity) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P_(complexity)"},{"title":"Talk:Complexity class - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Complexity_class"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the PSPACE complexity class:

## Definition

PSPACE is the set of all decision problems that can be solved by a Turing machine using a polynomial amount of space.

## Key Properties

The class PSPACE is closed under operations union, complementation, and Kleene star. Additionally, the complements of all problems in PSPACE are also in PSPACE, meaning that co-PSPACE = PSPACE.

## Relationship to Other Complexity Classes

The known relations between PSPACE and other complexity classes are: NL⊆P⊆NP⊆PH⊆PSPACE⊆EXPTIME⊆EXPSPACE. However, it is widely suspected that all are strict containments, though most of them remain unproven.

## Alternative Characterizations

PSPACE has several equivalent formulations:

- An alternative characterization of PSPACE is the set of problems decidable by an alternating Turing machine in polynomial time, sometimes called APTIME or just AP.

- A major result of complexity theory is that PSPACE can be characterized as all the languages recognizable by a particular interactive proof system, the one defining the class IP. In this system, there is an all-powerful prover trying to convince a randomized polynomial-time verifier that a string is in the language.

## Nondeterminism and PSPACE

Because of Savitch's theorem, NPSPACE is equivalent to PSPACE, essentially because a deterministic Turing machine can simulate a nondeterministic Turing machine without needing much more space (even though it may use much more time).

## PSPACE-Complete Problems

Problems known to be PSPACE-complete include determining properties of regular expressions and context-sensitive grammars, determining the truth of quantified Boolean formulas, step-by-step changes between solutions of combinatorial optimization problems, and many puzzles and games.

Here's what I found about the SYK (Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev) model:

## Overview

The Sachdev–Ye–Kitaev (SYK) model is an exactly solvable model initially proposed by Subir Sachdev and Jinwu Ye, and later modified by Alexei Kitaev to the present commonly used form.

## Historical Development

Sachdev proposed a solvable model of complex quantum entanglement in a metal which does not have any particle-like excitations in 1993, which was later extended to become the Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev model (SYK).

## Applications and Significance

The model is believed to bring insights into the understanding of strongly correlated materials and it also has a close relation with the discrete model of AdS/CFT.(no content)Many condensed matter systems, such as quantum dot coupled to topological superconducting wires, graphene flake with irregular boundary, and kagome optical lattice with impurities, are proposed to be modeled by it.

## Connections to Black Holes

A connection between the structure of quantum entanglement in the SYK model and in black holes was first proposed by Sachdev in 2010, and these connections have led to developments in the quantum theory of black holes.

## Quantum Simulation

Some variants of the model are amenable to digital quantum simulation, with pioneering experiments implemented in nuclear magnetic resonance.

Links: [{"title":"Euler–Arnold equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler–Arnold_equation"},{"title":"Liouville–Arnold theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liouville–Arnold_theorem"},{"title":"Geodesics as Hamiltonian flows - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodesics_as_Hamiltonian_flows"},{"title":"Euler equations (fluid dynamics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_equations_(fluid_dynamics)"},{"title":"Euler's equations (rigid body dynamics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler's_equations_(rigid_body_dynamics)"},{"title":"Arnold–Beltrami–Childress flow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arnold–Beltrami–Childress_flow"},{"title":"Lagrangian mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrangian_mechanics"},{"title":"Lagrangian and Eulerian specification of the flow field - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrangian_and_Eulerian_specification_of_the_flow_field"},{"title":"Euler–Lagrange equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler–Lagrange_equation"},{"title":"Rotation formalisms in three dimensions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotation_formalisms_in_three_dimensions"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the Euler–Arnold formalism:

## Overview

The Euler–Arnold equations are a class of partial differential equations (PDEs) that describe the geodesic flow on infinite-dimensional Lie groups equipped with right-invariant metrics.

## Historical Development

Introduced by Vladimir Arnold in 1966, this perspective unifies diverse PDEs arising in fluid dynamics, elasticity, and other areas, in a common geometrical framework.(no content)A rigorous formulation of the Euler–Arnold framework was given by Ebin and Marsden (1970).

## Key Concept

These equations generalize classical mechanical systems, such as rigid body motion and ideal fluid flow (Euler equation), by interpreting their evolution as geodesic flow on a group of transformations.(no content)The main idea is to geometrically interpret ODEs on infinite-dimensional manifolds as PDEs (and vice-versa).

## Applications

Many PDEs from fluid dynamics are just special cases of the Euler–Arnold equation when viewed from suitable Lie groups: Burgers' equation, Korteweg–De Vries equation, Camassa–Holm equation, Hunter–Saxton equation, and many more. Additionally, the Euler equations for fluid dynamics can be derived from the Euler–Arnold equation, and the Euler equations of rigid body dynamics can be derived from the same Euler-Arnold equation.

Based on the search results, here's information about the Euler–Arnold formalism:

## Overview

The Euler–Arnold equations are a class of partial differential equations (PDEs) that describe the geodesic flow on infinite-dimensional Lie groups equipped with right-invariant metrics.

## Historical Development

Introduced by Vladimir Arnold in 1966, this perspective unifies diverse PDEs arising in fluid dynamics, elasticity, and other areas, in a common geometrical framework.(no content)A rigorous formulation of the Euler–Arnold framework was given by Ebin and Marsden (1970).

## Key Concept

These equations generalize classical mechanical systems, such as rigid body motion and ideal fluid flow (Euler equation), by interpreting their evolution as geodesic flow on a group of transformations.(no content)The main idea is to geometrically interpret ODEs on infinite-dimensional manifolds as PDEs (and vice-versa).

## Applications

Many PDEs from fluid dynamics are just special cases of the Euler–Arnold equation when viewed from suitable Lie groups: Burgers' equation, Korteweg–De Vries equation, Camassa–Holm equation, Hunter–Saxton equation, and many more. Additionally, the Euler equations for fluid dynamics can be derived from the Euler–Arnold equation, and the Euler equations of rigid body dynamics can be derived from the same Euler-Arnold equation.

Web search results for query: "Chaotic system"

Links: [{"title":"Chaos theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaos_theory"},{"title":"Control of chaos - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_of_chaos"},{"title":"Chaos computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaos_computing"},{"title":"List of chaotic maps - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chaotic_maps"},{"title":"Dynamical systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_systems_theory"},{"title":"Chaotic mixing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaotic_mixing"},{"title":"Lorenz system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lorenz_system"},{"title":"Chua's circuit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chua's_circuit"},{"title":"Hyperchaos - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperchaos"},{"title":"Hamiltonian system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_system"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about chaotic systems:

## Overview

A chaotic system focuses on underlying patterns and deterministic laws of dynamical systems that are highly sensitive to initial conditions.(no content)Within the apparent randomness of chaotic complex systems, there are underlying patterns, interconnection, constant feedback loops, repetition, self-similarity, fractals and self-organization.

## Key Characteristics

**Sensitivity to Initial Conditions:** Small differences in initial conditions, such as those due to errors in measurements or due to rounding errors in numerical computation, can yield widely diverging outcomes for such dynamical systems, rendering long-term prediction of their behavior impossible in general.(no content)This sensitivity is popularly known as the "butterfly effect".

**Deterministic Yet Unpredictable:** Although these systems are deterministic, meaning that their future behavior follows a unique evolution and is fully determined by their initial conditions, with no random elements involved, this does not make them predictable.

## Examples

Chaotic behavior exists in many natural systems, including fluid flow, heartbeat irregularities, weather and climate. Other specific examples include:

- Chua's circuit is a simple electronic circuit that exhibits classic chaotic behavior.
- The Lorenz system describes chaotic behavior of fluid movement when subjected to heating.

## Applications

Chaos theory has applications in a variety of disciplines, including meteorology, anthropology, sociology, environmental science, computer science, engineering, economics, ecology, and pandemic crisis management.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev:

## Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) Model

The Sachdev–Ye–Kitaev (SYK) model is an exactly solvable model initially proposed by Subir Sachdev and Jinwu Ye, and later modified by Alexei Kitaev to the present commonly used form.

### Significance and Applications

The model is believed to bring insights into the understanding of strongly correlated materials and it also has a close relation with the discrete model of AdS/CFT.(no content)Many condensed matter systems, such as quantum dot coupled to topological superconducting wires, graphene flake with irregular boundary, and kagome optical lattice with impurities, are proposed to be modeled by it.

### Research Directions

Some variants of the model are amenable to digital quantum simulation, with pioneering experiments implemented in nuclear magnetic resonance.

The model represents an important contribution at the intersection of condensed matter physics and black hole physics, with contributions to the study of quantum chaos and holography.

Based on the search results, here's information about the Euler–Arnold equation:

## Overview

The Euler–Arnold equations are a class of partial differential equations (PDEs) that describe the geodesic flow on infinite-dimensional Lie groups equipped with right-invariant metrics.

## Key Characteristics

These equations generalize classical mechanical systems, such as rigid body motion and ideal fluid flow (Euler equation), by interpreting their evolution as geodesic flow on a group of transformations.(no content)They describe the evolution of a velocity field when the Lagrangian flow is a geodesic in a group of smooth transformations.

## Historical Development

Introduced by Vladimir Arnold in 1966, this perspective unifies diverse PDEs arising in fluid dynamics, elasticity, and other areas, in a common geometrical framework.(no content)Arnold presented a common geometric interpretation for both the Euler's equations for rotating rigid bodies and the Euler's equations of fluid dynamics, which effectively linked topics previously thought to be unrelated.

## Applications

In hydrodynamics, they serve the purpose of describing the motion of inviscid, incompressible fluids.(no content)Many PDEs from fluid dynamics are just special cases of the Euler–Arnold equation when viewed from suitable Lie groups: Burgers' equation, Korteweg–De Vries equation, Camassa–Holm equation, Hunter–Saxton equation, and many more.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "eigenstate quantum mechanics"

Links: [{"title":"Quantum state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_state"},{"title":"Stationary state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stationary_state"},{"title":"Quantum mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_mechanics"},{"title":"Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenstate_thermalization_hypothesis"},{"title":"Eigenfunction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenfunction"},{"title":"Position operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Position_operator"},{"title":"Observable - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observable"},{"title":"Complete set of commuting observables - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_set_of_commuting_observables"},{"title":"Eigenspinor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenspinor"},{"title":"Momentum operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Momentum_operator"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about eigenstates in quantum mechanics:

## Definition

A quantum state can be an eigenvector of an observable, in which case it is called an eigenstate, and the associated eigenvalue corresponds to the value of the observable in that eigenstate.

## Key Characteristics

These solution states, called eigenstates, are labeled with quantized values, typically quantum numbers.(no content)The corresponding eigenvector (which physicists call an eigenstate) with eigenvalue 1 kg⋅m/s would be a quantum state with a definite, well-defined value of momentum of 1 kg⋅m/s, with no quantum uncertainty.

## Measurement Properties

When a quantum system is in a specific eigenstate of an observable, measurements of that observable yield definite results. Suppose that the system is in an eigenstate of B at the experiment's beginning. If we measure only B, all runs of the experiment will yield the same result.

## Superposition

A pure state described as a superposition of multiple different eigenstates does in general have quantum uncertainty for the given observable.

## Specific Examples

A stationary state is an eigenvector of the energy operator (instead of a quantum superposition of different energies). It is also called energy eigenvector, energy eigenstate, energy eigenfunction, or energy eigenket.

Eigenstates are fundamental to quantum mechanics because they represent states where physical observables have definite, measurable values without uncertainty.
